subjectDescription: Discover a full suite of online business courses that will allow you to make better business decisions and succeed in today's competitive business world. Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Fundamentals of Six Sigma (6Ïƒ) - Six Sigma White Belt
headline: In this free online course learn the basics of Six Sigma White Belt and its implementation.
description: This free online course on Six Sigma White Belt explains the basic principles of Six Sigma. You will also be introduced to the other Six Sigma Belts together with their roles in a project and the purpose of Six Sigma Champion and Six Sigma Executive. You will learn the different explanations, procedures, perspectives, techniques, methodologies, metrics, and philosophies of Six Sigma and the different approaches to its implementation.
courseDescription:
In this free online course Six Sigma White Belt, you will learn about the basic principles of Six Sigma and its comparison with Lean. You will learn how to combine Lean and Six Sigma to make it more beneficial for the organization. You will learn different definitions of Six Sigma together with its perspectives, techniques, methodologies and metrics. You will also learn different approaches to implementing Six Sigma and their respective descriptions. In addition, you will learn the different tools of Six Sigma which it uses to implement its processes.

Next, the DMAIC approach is explained along with a description of its five phases. After that, the DMAIC procedures are explained. Then, the DMADV approach is introduced and explained and both approaches are compared and contrasted. Each of the Six Sigma Belts is introduced and described, before the roles of the Six Sigma Champion and Six Sigma Executive are explained. Lastly, Six Sigma certifications are introduced along with their roles in an organization.

After completing this free course, you will gain valuable information about the basic concepts of Six Sigma. This knowledge is beneficial for anyone working in the business world at any level. White Belts can not only assist with change management within an organization, but they can also participate in local problem-solving teams that support projects. These are valuable skills, so why wait? Enrol now and start learning today!

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital : a downloadable in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • : a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked , posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed : a physical version of your officially branded and security marked in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

All are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison , please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison , you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. slides:
• Learning Outcomes
    • Describe the concept of Six Sigma.
    • Explain the Six Sigma DMAIC methodology.
    • Outline the tools and techniques of Six Sigma.
    • Describe the philosophical perspective and metrics of Six Sigma.
    • Evaluate the statistical tools of Six Sigma.
    • Outline how to implement Six Sigma and the different approaches for its implementation.
    • Explain the four aspects of the Six Sigma philosophy.
    • Differentiate between Lean and Six Sigma. 
  • Introduction to Six Sigma
  • Six Sigma is a method that helps organizations to improve various production capabilities of their business processes by providing them with certain tools and techniques. It helps to increase the overall performance while at the same time, reduces process variation. This helps the business to identify defect reduction areas and do well to earn high profits in the long run. Moreover, it improves the morale of the employee, and the quality of the services and products that the company provides.

  • The Approaches to Implement Six Sigma
  • In order to enhance their business capabilities, businesses opt for different tools and strategies. One such tool is Six Sigma that helps businesses to increase their overall performance as well as reducing their process variation. It also helps the businesses identify reduction and increase in their profits, the morale of their employee, and the quality of the services and products they provide.

    • Alignment of goals

    • Once an organization decides to establish and implement Six Sigma, it is crucial to maintain the smooth running of all the business operations. It should be noted however, that this improvement should not only be in the terms of generating profits but also in several other areas such as safety, product quality, cycle time, and production cost.

  • Lesson Summary
    • Six Sigma is a management philosophy that helps organizations enhance their manufacturing operations. It helps organizations by making efficient use of statistical tools which improves the efficiency and quality of their output.
    • Six Sigma achieves this by keeping a record of the organizationsâ€™ data, setting objectives, and then going through their results so that it can minimize the magnitude of faults in the business operations of these organizations.
    • Six Sigma intends to detect the defects in the operations of the organizations after which they will be able to eliminate those defects in a systematic manner.
    • There is a prime focus on the DMAIC approach to solving problems. DMAIC is an acronym for Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, and Control.
    • All the organizational levels are provided training in statistical thinking whereas the key people of the organization train in advanced statistics and project management. These key people are known as Black Belts.
    • The Philosophical Perspective of Six Sigma: These processes need inputs (x) to produce outputs (y). Controlling the inputs will result in controlling the output. This statement can be represented in the form of an equation as y=f(x).
  • Lesson Summary
    • Six Sigma is a management philosophy that helps organizations enhance their manufacturing operations. It helps organizations by making efficient use of statistical tools which improves the efficiency and quality of their output.
    • Six Sigma achieves this by keeping a record of the organizationsâ€™ data, setting objectives, and then going through their results so that it can minimize the magnitude of faults in the business operations of these organizations.
    • Six Sigma intends to detect the defects in the operations of the organizations after which they will be able to eliminate those defects in a systematic manner.
    • There is a prime focus on the DMAIC approach to solving problems. DMAIC is an acronym for Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, and Control.
    • All the organizational levels are provided training in statistical thinking whereas the key people of the organization train in advanced statistics and project management. These key people are known as Black Belts.
    • The Philosophical Perspective of Six Sigma: These processes need inputs (x) to produce outputs (y). Controlling the inputs will result in controlling the output. This statement can be represented in the form of an equation as y=f(x).
  • Lesson Summary
    • Six Sigma is a management philosophy that helps organizations enhance their manufacturing operations. It helps organizations by making efficient use of statistical tools which improves the efficiency and quality of their output.
    • Six Sigma achieves this by keeping a record of the organizationsâ€™ data, setting objectives, and then going through their results so that it can minimize the magnitude of faults in the business operations of these organizations.
    • Six Sigma intends to detect the defects in the operations of the organizations after which they will be able to eliminate those defects in a systematic manner.
    • There is a prime focus on the DMAIC approach to solving problems. DMAIC is an acronym for Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, and Control.
    • All the organizational levels are provided training in statistical thinking whereas the key people of the organization train in advanced statistics and project management. These key people are known as Black Belts.
    • The Philosophical Perspective of Six Sigma: These processes need inputs (x) to produce outputs (y). Controlling the inputs will result in controlling the output. This statement can be represented in the form of an equation as y=f(x).

  • Learning Outcomes
    • Explain the concept of DMAIC.
    • Outline the DMAIC approach to process improvement.
    • Describe DMAIC procedures.
    • Explain what DMADV stands for and outline the DMADV approach.
    • Distinguish between DMAIC and DMADV.
    • List the Six Sigma Belts and explain their roles in a project.
    • State the roles of a Six Sigma Champion and a Six Sigma Executive.
    • Describe the certifications of Six Sigma.
  • DMAIC approach of process improvement
  • Six Sigma has three aspects that are necessary for any organization that wants to implement it. The DMAIC approach is the technical aspect of the Six Sigma program. It is a data-driven quality strategy that helps organizations to improve their processes.
  • DMAIC: Five Phases
  • The DMAIC approach stands for Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, and Control. These five phases make up the process. It also includes tools such as design or redesign which are used to complete these phases. The DMAIC approach is an integral part of the Six Sigma initiative but organizations can also implement it as a separate procedure for quality improvement. It can also be incorporated in other process improvement initiatives such as Lean.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Six Sigma Belts and Roles in a Project
  • Six Sigma is a methodology that helps organizations improve business processes. It also helps organizations to develop business processes based on a given problem. Different Six Sigma professionals exist at different organizational levels.
  • The Six Sigma professionals carry different designations with themselves. At the project level, there are the following designations of Six Sigma professionals:
    • Master Black Belt
    • Black Belt
    • Green Belt
    • Yellow Belt
    • White Belt
    • Brown Belt
  • Six Sigma Belts and Roles in a Project

  • The Six Sigma professionals carry different designations with themselves. At the project level, there are the following designations of Six Sigma professionals:

    • Black Belt
    • Green Belt

    • Brown Belt

  • Lesson Summary
    • The DMAIC approach stands for Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, and Control.
    • The DMAIC approach is an integral part of the Six Sigma initiative but organizations can also implement it as a separate procedure for quality improvement.
    • Six Sigma has three aspects that are necessary for any organization that wants to implement it. The DMAIC approach of process involvement is part of the technical aspect of the Six Sigma program. It is a data-driven quality strategy that helps organizations to improve their processes.
    • The DMADV approach stands for Define, Measure, Analyze, Design, and Verify.
    • Differences between DMAIC & DMADV:
      - Framework
      - Steps
      - Correction v/s Prevention
      - Quantitative Tools v/s Qualitative Tools
      - Focus
      - Approach
      - Duration
    • Designations of Six Sigma at the project level: Master Black Belt, Black Belt, Green Belt, Yellow Belt, White Belt, and Brown Belt.
